I was a judge for twenty years -- and no one ever succeeded in using the defense that others managed to commit the crime and got away with it. It does not work for the "retail" criminal shoplifters and domestic abusers, and it does not work for those who commit their crimes "wholesale". The fact that the system should be doing more to stop this reprehensible behavior does not mean that we should not try to stop it. This is an issue of what society tolerates, not what individual politicians do or don't do.

Northstar, my take on philosophy is that it stopped making significant contributions to our understanding of morality sometime in the 20th century. I would never gainsay the contributions of the ancients, or Kant or Nietzsche or Rawls. But when philosophy and scientific inquiry parted ways, philosophy lost its way. So while I agree that moral philosophy continues to be important locally I don't believe that its global foundations are sound in light of contemporary knowledge

Most assume a golden rule/categorical imperative foundation for philosophy. But things are not that simple. It can be argued that the greatest good doesn't necessarily proceed from the golden rule. One sees moral inequality in communities of animals, and one sees it commonly in communities of men, including our own.

The matter is doubly compounded when one considers that the memes that constitute culture compete. The morality that survives and propagates is to a first approximation the morality of the culture that prevails. This can have unpleasant human consequences. An early agricultural society that practiced slavery, for example, the most efficient economic organization of that time, typically prevailed over egalitarian hunter-gatherer societies. Thus slavery spread. It ended when capitalism was developed, and proved more successful at that stage of technological and social development.

Come now, Mr. Bayard. What of the slow blossoming of esteem, then friendship, then . . . something more between Barrow and Andy? The Dowager Duchess has finally gotten her own romance (which has given her a great deal more depth); and now it's Thomas' turn to transcend the suffering Sodomite convention he's been trapped in all these years. As long as he doesn't pounce as he did on Jimmy. I hear that footmen like a man that takes his time.
I liked Jane Lapotaire's (as the Princess) one-note performance as the embodiment of ruined privilege and blasted hopes. But then . . . have you actually met my mother-in-law?
Glass houses indeed go back very far. But Lady Rose said tonight, "It's called marriage," which is a very recent, snappy locution. The anachronism of verbal formulas (rather than proverbial expressions) seems pretty common. But you never know. Lord Grantham once said that something was "not his thing," which seemed odd to me, but it coincidentally popped up in a Wodehouse novel that week.
And how great would it be if Downton intersected with other Anglophile classics? If the Dowager Duchess turned out to be a pal of Bertie Wooster's terrifying Aunt Agatha? (Come to think of it, they *have* to be related.) Or if Mapp tried to impress all Tilling and humiliate Lucia with her intimate knowledge of the Abbey?

I have looked at the mathematics PARCC test that has been in the news recently.  These tests certainly look reasonable.  As a chemistry professor who routinely teaches freshman chemistry, I assume that students know how to do the mathematics on the practice tests that I saw.  Sadly, it is true that many (approximately 40%) of students that we see today cannot do the mathematics on the PARCC test when they enter college.  I attribute this to the fact that -- before common core standard -- students only needed to get 35% of the questions correct on the Math A (Algebra I) Regents exam to "pass" the exam (i.e., earn a 60).  This contributes to poor performance and retention in STEM disciplines in college.  Thus, while I understand that this is difficult for parents, I support the increase in standards in high schools.

High stakes tests are tests where scores do have a significant impact on the educational environment of a school. More and more schools are being graded on test scores, and it's not enough to have high scores. No, the problem for affluent schools and selective admission schools is that now in addition those "high" scores must show "growth" as dictated by complex algorithms. Every year scores must go higher to "prove" that a child's teacher has given them a "full year of growth." And the sole measure of growth is the test score. It is not based on more authentic measures., really just those scores. So what is forced to be taught is the content of the test, because teachers in many states can be fired for not showing enough "growth." Do a search for an open letter by PS 321. It is a school with "high" scores. The teachers know they cannot make those kids go "higher" every year, and so their jobs are in jeopardy. They are asking for parents in those schools to speak out about these high-stakes. My daughter is in school in Philadelphia. Here, they use the quest for "high-performing" seats to justify closing neighborhood schools and giving them to charter companies. They are giving our schools away based on flawed data. You may not feel the high-stakes yet in Montclair. But ed-reform is all consuming. Soon they will come after your schools-once ours have been chewed up and spit out. No one is safe. Don't be fooled, these are very high-stakes.

How is it that these are called "high stakes"? At least here in Montclair, there are zero stakes. A 10 point quiz counts for more to a student. But calling these "high stakes" fits the narrative, which is intended to frighten parents.

Just last week, an employee of our school district called my wife's statement at a Board of Ed meeting "pathetic". One of our sons had been greatly inspired by his language arts teacher in one of our elementary schools, and he ended up writing a book. But praising this teacher's creativity, and expressing gratitude for how she encouraged our son's own creativity, breaks the narrative of fear.

Unfortunately, fear is easy to inspire in us parents; we care so much for our children. More: for years I've heard other parents lamenting their inability to help their children with math homework. I took that as a positive sign: math education is improving. Now, however, those same parents are judging what a math test should or should not include. That threatens to set a cap on what we can teach our kids: what we learned, and no more. The same way we learned, and no different. This leaves no room for improvement in what is taught or how it is taught.

I believe we should strive for precisely the opposite. I believe that my job as a parent - and the job of our schools - is achieved when our children surpass us. It is wrong for us to try to hold them back for reasons of either fear or ego.

...Andrew

John,

In an earlier comment I said that I was for national standards but with minimal use of bubble-tests.

We see misunderstanding and misuse of numbers all the time, and this kind of testing it is pretty much looking under the streetlight for the keys you lost in the alley. Sure you get numbers, but you are only measuring what can be measured by those kinds of tests.

How about this: If you want to evaluate a *school*, take a random (statistically significant) sample of students and have them interact with a team of outside testers, using exercises and interviews. It could even be done remotely. Sure, use a bunch of metrics with numerical rankings if you like in the final report.

I'm not even sure it would cost *that* much more in total, although the money would go to individuals rather than corporate profits.

Then, let the teachers deal with the individuals within the total population, for which their daily contact makes them far better qualified.

Learning how to take a test is not real learning. If we want to remain competitive in the world we need kids who are passionate about knowledge, creative, innovative, and capable of critical thinking—not test-taking robots who've been drilled on material they'll soon forget anyway. I very much sympathize with those who choose to opt out.

"Common Core can't solve all of these problems"

No. But it, along with related testing, may provide more accurate information, both per-student and on a wider scale, regarding these problems. Perhaps we'll reach a point where they can no longer be ignored.

My district has been trying more, more recently, to identify students having difficulty as early as possible. This does mean testing. But it also means kids getting help earlier.

I've a similar hope that better/earlier information can help schools and even districts to spot (and therefore correct) problems before they become too serious or more costly to our children.

So it doesn't matter if you're contributing to the collapse of American civilization as long as your lobby is gaudily appointed. Poor, old New Yorkland.

While my apartment building is not as gorgeous as these structures, until recently most apartments had many original details from when it was constructed in 1929.  In an attempt to update the building to modern (bad) tastes, many distinctive features -- terra cotta hallway walls, picture frame moldings, patterned radiator covers, sconces, pedestal sinks, arch doorways, lighting fixtures from the 20s, faceted crystal doorknobs -- have been destroyed and tenants could be living in any old plain vanilla building from the 50s.

None of those places was ever really a place for the middle class. Unless you had a job in one and passed through the Art Deco lobby on your way to the elevators.

Once upon a time, our banks too were beautiful. Middle-class and working-class families who were able to put away a little bit every month, or at the least had to wait in line in order to deposit a weekly paycheck and take a little cash out for groceries in the days before ATMs, were able to gaze around them at interiors designed to inspire confidence.

Pretty sure the middle class, of any decade, never spent much time in these lobbies.

These gilded age towers have always been for the super rich.

It remains to be demonstrated that those who make lots of money have "earned" it.

There are more than a few who might argue that it has been stolen (if not in the criminal sense).

lovely. and not a single one of these restorations is going to be affordable to the now largely diminished middle class.

Everything in nyc is now for the very very very rich.

such a shame.

When the old Cunard Building on lower Broadway goes condo, I will be first in line to buy.  I still remember when the lobby was a post office.  It was the one time in my life I did not mind waiting to be served.  Gazing at those spectacular frescoes of the places Cunard sailed, to say nothing of the fabulous mosaics in the floor was a visual feast.

The article and commenters seem oblivious to the existence of federal and New York State Historic Tax Credits which are very powerful financing tools that provide a bottom line offset against an investors tax liability (not an income offset but a tax liability offset).

An historic renovation may be a good marketing tool, but it is a better way to finance the high cost of redevelopment in New York City.

The floor of 52 Clark Street in Brooklyn Heights had intricate American Indian style tiles, including Swastikas in the opposite of Nazi designs. A decade ago, they were destroyed, replaced by bland white tiles that also cover the walls.

I am happy to say that 10 East 40th Street, where I worked decades ago, installed a bland drop ceiling in an effort to "modernize" the building. This has now been removed, and the intricate terra cotta ceiling has been fully restored.

There are now tours of the Woolworth Building's lobby, which was closed to all visitors following the 9/11 attacks. This deprived thousands of visitors the opportunity to see the lobby of this "Cathedral of Commerce."
